NOTICE is hereby given, that the President
and Managers fthe Newcastle and Frenchaown
Turnpike have declared dividend for the last
six months, at the rate of six per cent. per an
mum, on the capital stock ofthe Company, which
will be paid by the Treasurer to the Stockholders
or their legal representatives, at any time after
the 25th inst.


Notice is also given that an election will be
held at the house of Bennett Lewis, in the tow n
of New astle, on Thursday the 29th of March,
inst :, between the hours of2 and O'Clock p.
NJ for the purpose of choosing President, four
Managers and Treasurer, to conduct the affairs
of the Company for the ensuing year.


JAMES COUpER, IreQS'r.

Do our ccsioaS flow from necessity or :rom
choicc2 This has always been subject OF
discussion. Itappears to me, but with de-
gree of uncertainty, that our actions How
from necessity and not from choice, as ma
ny suppose Persons will generally admit
that they consult their interest and pleasure
in every undertaking or in every act. We
all have great desire tc commit such acts
as will benefit or please iii any way whatc-
yer, or such acts as will give us our choice;
then in order to produce such benefit or
pleasure, or in order 20 obtain our choice,
we are compelled or rneccssitated to act in 4
certain manner; therefore it appears that
our actions flow from necessity. We choose
pleasing and beneficial consequences, and to
produce such consequences, we are necessl-
tated to make use of the right causes. 1t
seems it is by actlngin a certain way that we
obtain choice; hence an act follows neces-
sity, and choice follows an act--th's IS in
variably the relation that they appear 70 me
to stand in, one to another.


Ifa philanthropist renders an INDECENT per-
son pecunlary aid, he is we'll pleased: but
what pleascs him? 1t is not the act OF Civ
ing the money, but the effect thatfact pro-
duced, which was the poor mans relief from
suffering. He was necessitated to do the act
or cause, because he chose to be pleased
with the effect. When gratified with the
good circumstance (the poor mans deliver
ance from want) arising out of his good act,
he has gained the object aimed at, which is
cho;ce.-Thus, it seems, our actions flow
from necessity; and by our actions we OBTAIN
choice.


This is question that am not capable
of making any advantageous remarks upon

Daring Rob5ery.-On Thusday after
noon about 5 o'clock, two Williams entered
the house of Mr.. Cramp, in Kensington, by
the alley gate, boiling the same behind
them, and commenced a conversation with
his daughter, enquired il that was not the
same house which had been robbed some
wears before, and If she was the same that
the robbers had struck at that time-she am
swered yes. They then proceeded to tie
her hands behind her back; stabbed her un-
der the right breast; made her tell where
the munev was; took off her fing,-tied a
handkerchief round her neck to slltocate
her cries; took the watch (Which they lett
behind them in hnrry) and struck her on the
arm violent blow; we do not hear that any
further insult was offered to the young lady.
Several neighbors Immediately joined and
made every possible search, but to no pur-
pose; so the miscreants are yet loose Oh So
ciety.--I'hila. Pallad.
Bran(lvwine Hundred, March 30, 1927.

oh; we cont intend to take our leave OF you,

Oh, Billy, the public at large secs you delneat-

what the people III England calls Pasldys garrett

There are moments OF reflection which
press upon us in the midst of gaiety, and
they sometimes bring with them admonito-
ry lessons. We were seated in corner of
room, at the Bachelors Ball, watching
the ladies as they promenaded, and passed
a merited eulogium on the neatness OF
their dress, the propriety and modesty of
department, and their whole appearance
"They are very WELL" said friend of the
haat ron, near me, "but they are not the
I fashion of our cty--clever girls enough
4 daughters of worthy traders and industrious
mechanics; but they have not the "entree"
I into fashionable society; they are not known
4 beyond Pearl street or Chatam square.
"What constitutes fashion," "Why, wealth,
talent, certain ar---a Jeen Sais quoi" 1t
4 is wealth, there are Sin Young ladies whose
4 fathers can each draw check for 100000,
which shall be honored." MAY be So
but they wear pepper and salt CO atees with
lime on them-dine at half past one, and
Keep no carriage"


4 Thus we sum up the attributes of what is
i called fashionable life. The lady, though
y She is handsome, intelligent, rich and re-
\ spectacle, cannot be voted fashionable, un-
I I'll some priestess at the shrine, places her
q among the initiated, or some dandy declares
1 mat she will do. How absurd. In Eng
N iand, where there are hereditary claims, and
Z privileged orders, the adhesion OF the aris'
Il s.ocracs is necessary to the preservation o
4 yaeir order; but in this country, where nei
n ther fortune, birth nor talent can be entail
ea'it is ridiculous to defend such discrimin


auons The energies of clever man, arr
ssrrepressible. Half of what is called til,


.ashlon of New York-the bon ton--the We
r y y, leaders Of taste, are sprung from homes


.shors and industrious carpenters; bnt thu


ace desenerates. Fathers have raised them


sseNes by their ewn talent and enterpriz,


.10n' the bottom to the top of the ladder
FASHION.

The President has issued his proclamation
closing the ports of the United States a
gainst all British vessels coming from any
colonial port belonging to his Britanic Ma
jesty. In allusion to the proclamation OF
the President, the Editor Of the National
Journal remarks:


"rhc law, it should seem, does not au-
thorzc the President 70 issue his Proclama
ton to take effect prospectivcly; but such
steps will of course be taken by the cxecu-
tive as candor and equity require in regard
to such vessels as are now in port, or may
arrive in the United States without having
received previous knowledge Of the presi-
dents Proclamation.


We certainly could have wished that Con
gross should have so left this matter as that
the British Government might have seen
distinctly, and in the form oflaw, the terms
on which the United States were willing TO
open the Colonial Trade TO both parties, and
full consideration Of those terms. AS Con
gress, however, saw fit to pass no new law,





carry into execution such laws as do exist,
according to its sense Of duty The contin-
gcncy provided forby existing laws has hap
pened, and Congress having risen without
altering those laws nothing has remained
to the Executive bat to give effect to those


laws, in conformity with their requirement.
.


Our advices from Portugal are favorable
to the cause and success of the friends to
the Constitution. The rebel, or royal rrces,
as they are called, have been dispersed, and
their leader, the Marquis de Chavcs, on
whom their best hopes were founded, been
put to aght-wounded and disgraced, he
has been compelled to seek an asylum in
the territory of the King Of Spain. Fer
dinand publicly disclams taking any part
in the rupture i'll Portugal, but many cir
cumstances have disclo ,cd the fact, tina,
both money and munitions of war have been
literally distributed among the disaffccted,
by his agents. We believe that tranquil,
ity will shortly be restored by the Britisi
troops; but that it will be Of long duration
is a thing quite improbable. The ambition
of the priests, who arc determined to have
their weight in the scale of all politica
measures, will keep the people continually
restless, and plot after plot will be got VI
by them, to overthrow the Constitutions
,, Government. We have no idea that an,
! plot having such an object in view, can eve
succeed. The peasantry may be reused
time after time, to take up arms and assume


the aspect of revolt, but they must as speed


lily be again put down, when the scaiiol'
l will smoke with the blood of its deiude'
t victims, and the instigators, the real wiz
workers of civil discord. will be shede
. !, from the punishment due them, by the awe
inspiring influence of the Church. The onl


safeguard to the public veal will be, wis


policy in the administration of the Govern
i ment,

On the 18th ult the log hut Of a colored
man named Daniel Annette, was burnt, at
Ashtabula, Ohio. together with his three
children! The mans wife had left him,
and he usually locked his children in the
house during the day, which was the case
on the above fatal morning.

Young Ladies Boarding School,


ar WILMINGTON, DELAWARE.
full articles.article:
Under the s,lpei.intcmlcnce and instruction OF
WlILIAsi SilfsER, assisted by accomplished
female teachers


The course of instruction pursued at this sem
iparv, comprises I'LL the useful, and most ot the
Ornamental branches Of female education .hc
daily exercises are Orthography, Reading, Writ
ng. Arithmetic, English Grammar, Rhetorc;
Geography and History, ancient and modern,
with constant reference to the be < maps and
charts; Construction of maps; use Of the Globes;
Natural History; Natural Philosophy, including
Astronomy and Chemistry; Elemcnts OF Moral
Science.


Jtleklg E1erciscs. Biblical Recitaions; Erl-
dences of Christianity; Letter rlting, ana o'ii'
CT species of Compositions; Recapitulalons.


It,ms-Boarl and tuition, in any Of the tore,
going branches, s52, 50 per quarter; or, Ii pait
in atlya.ce, $50. Music, including the use OF a
piano, S12, French, hv one of the best masters,
SC per quarter. Moderate extra charges foi
Drawing and other ornamental! branches.


The discipline of the school is mild, parental,
and christian. Particular attention IS paid not
only TO the manners of the young ladies'. but tc
their moral and religious instruction. They are
regularly conducted to such places of worship
and Sunday Schools, as Their parents and guar
elians approve. Exercise and recreation, being
essential to the preservation OF health and o
mental energy. occupy the intervals ot tune no
devoted to study. The institution, in all its dc
partments, is conducted in mannner which j
is hoped, will meet the entire appreciation Of it
patrons.

bert; Hon. w. HALL lion. Louis AfL.anc: Fhih
de'phia-Rev. DIR. Wilson; Rev. DIR Janewas

Thompson, Esq. Professor Of Languages, IN
versity Of pennss lyania.

full articles.headline: Dividend and Election.
full articles.article:
NOTICE is hereby given, that the President
and Managers fthe Newcastle and Frenchaown
Turnpike have declared dividend for the last
six months, at the rate of six per cent. per an
mum, on the capital stock ofthe Company, which
will be paid by the Treasurer to the Stockholders
or their legal representatives, at any time after
the 25th inst.


Notice is also given that an election will be
held at the house of Bennett Lewis, in the tow n
of New astle, on Thursday the 29th of March,
inst :, between the hours of2 and O'Clock p.
NJ for the purpose of choosing President, four
Managers and Treasurer, to conduct the affairs
of the Company for the ensuing year.


JAMES COUpER, IreQS'r.
Newcastle, Del. March H. 1927.

full articles.headline:
s------~@

For Tie IKlAningtontaN.
full articles.article:
Do our ccsioaS flow from necessity or :rom
choicc2 This has always been subject OF
discussion. Itappears to me, but with de-
gree of uncertainty, that our actions How
from necessity and not from choice, as ma
ny suppose Persons will generally admit
that they consult their interest and pleasure
in every undertaking or in every act. We
all have great desire tc commit such acts
as will benefit or please iii any way whatc-
yer, or such acts as will give us our choice;
then in order to produce such benefit or
pleasure, or in order 20 obtain our choice,
we are compelled or rneccssitated to act in 4
certain manner; therefore it appears that
our actions flow from necessity. We choose
pleasing and beneficial consequences, and to
produce such consequences, we are necessl-
tated to make use of the right causes. 1t
seems it is by actlngin a certain way that we
obtain choice; hence an act follows neces-
sity, and choice follows an act--th's IS in
variably the relation that they appear 70 me
to stand in, one to another.


Ifa philanthropist renders an INDECENT per-
son pecunlary aid, he is we'll pleased: but
what pleascs him? 1t is not the act OF Civ
ing the money, but the effect thatfact pro-
duced, which was the poor mans relief from
suffering. He was necessitated to do the act
or cause, because he chose to be pleased
with the effect. When gratified with the
good circumstance (the poor mans deliver
ance from want) arising out of his good act,
he has gained the object aimed at, which is
cho;ce.-Thus, it seems, our actions flow
from necessity; and by our actions we OBTAIN
choice.


This is question that am not capable
of making any advantageous remarks upon

dark hole on the hill, permitme again to ap-
pear in your useful journal, to exhibit to
its readers the absurdity and arrogancy of
the remarks of an" in reply to Lodge
Hill" in your last number, and as ''brevity
is the soul of w.t." we will conhne ourselves
to the subject in dispute. n. recently APP
peared in your columns with an arithmeti-
Cal question to be solved-Lodgc Hill had
the wonderful audaclty to propose all answer
---annihilation must then ensue, and the
hole must be our doom. Such egotism and
folly AS n. has exhibited, argues not we'll
but to the subject: the question that N. pro-
posed, he has not yet wrought. In his an
swer to +. he says he makes use of no multi
plication whatever He then, in the same
column, says. suppose then we multiply
- G. M


9 90 9


RV

.,,- the still more touching feco'ice,
pcss' e d,I the grains he had given them-anu
floa =. ,sd . on the happy spot where ne hau
aFga',n ~ cid them, but "they were not, aha
)as, n.nS VAS before him but the blackness OF
nolh,,"S; And as one living thing IN SOL
tieso'ar,k rnakes it yet more gloomy, SO was the
'tuds nf the scene heightened by the pres,
r'lse'y ,he solitary, bereaved gander, around
enec u nack was fastened small bag, IN
whosse ..e owner found shilling, and slip
F#hicn .nsr sr0 containing, not pound note, but
/ N he following exquisite stanza;
Mr.. Blight, Mr., Blight,
We wish you good night,
FOR we cannot stay any longer
We have bought all your geese
Alta penny apiece,
And left the amount with the gandef'

and instead of placing their sons in the same
position, and compelling them to raise by
their own merits, they place them on the top
Of the ladder, and they must go downwards
From this cause, the next generation of fash
ionables of New York will be poor creatures.
a great man you can never put down, and
small man you can never make great
Hence then we see small man swelling
himself into importance, and attempting to
had the fashions, which gives him his right

full articles.headline: Bran(lvwine Hundred, March 30, 1927.
full articles.article:
Daring Rob5ery.-On Thusday after
noon about 5 o'clock, two Williams entered
the house of Mr.. Cramp, in Kensington, by
the alley gate, boiling the same behind
them, and commenced a conversation with
his daughter, enquired il that was not the
same house which had been robbed some
wears before, and If she was the same that
the robbers had struck at that time-she am
swered yes. They then proceeded to tie
her hands behind her back; stabbed her un-
der the right breast; made her tell where
the munev was; took off her fing,-tied a
handkerchief round her neck to slltocate
her cries; took the watch (Which they lett
behind them in hnrry) and struck her on the
arm violent blow; we do not hear that any
further insult was offered to the young lady.
Several neighbors Immediately joined and
made every possible search, but to no pur-
pose; so the miscreants are yet loose Oh So
ciety.--I'hila. Pallad.

full articles.headline:
A PUBLIC EXHIBITION

Of Tr1!Aam Larain's .h;s7v System cthayMg


Old Debts.
full articles.article:
Master Billy, are you not ashamed to call me
quandam quack, as the public sees that my .ial
tabnras pills had a more cfectual and powerful
operation on your system than all the medicine
you have taken these FIVE years past: for my sal
taburas pills. caused you to quit the field OF acs
ton in a short and dirty hurry, without seconoi
appeal TO the public or an apology for the con-
tcmptuous treatment you have given the public;
by your endeavoring to impose false assertion,
which you had to swallow dog does his vom-'
it. We had taken the shorte stand planest way
to prove that you was imposing on the public
with the most bare faced falsehood, which W L
put a stop to, when we challenged you to call n
any three, FOUR or more of the respectable me
in this borough, and appoint your time, and we
would meet you face to face, and if you COULD
produce one receipt OF settlement from the truss
tees of st. Peters Church, for any sum OF mo'
new even for one dollar, from the commencement
Of the drawing of the Lottery until this day, we.
would acknowledge your assertion to be true
We gave you forty light hours to come forwards
you did not appear--neither could you IN forty-
eight wears with the documents demanded, so'
that YOU prove yourtelf TO be l--r for offering
such false assertions to the public In your state
ment ofthe sale of the two first classes OF the
lottery there is falsehood a school boy may
with the glance of one eye, see: where you
state YOU sold the two first classes of the lottery
for $500 each, which sums made but $1,000; and
you tell the public you paid the church out OF
the proceeds Of these two classes the sum OF
$1605 here Blly you prove yourself false agair'
Billy you hold the proceeds OF the lottery hve
years and finding your postulatums cannot be
any longer imposed on the public, nor your
pseudo account without day or date, be any long.
er suffered 10 procrastinate your prohtarlous I'M
passions as respects your honest actions respect
ing the lottery in your farewell to the trustees
and your respected friend the q,landaln quack.
oh; we cont intend to take our leave OF you,
dear Billy, as we have found your bond which
you passed to Governor Collins, which binds you
in the penalty of ten thousand dollars to discharge
Che trust the church confded in you. 1t spos-
sibIe Billy as you now in the possession of
this fact t,.at if it was more convenient to you,
YOU would prefer the trustees and the quandam
we're in Guinea. What did you do with the four
writs YOU had marked out against the four trus-
tees for scandazing your character, by inform
ing the public that you held both pew rent sub
scription and lottery money from the church,
Oh, Billy, the public at large secs you delneat-
ed in your real colours. You swore that the
four trustees you took cut wrts against was for
leaving the state, or something to that effect
to prevent them of saying any thing more about
YOUR honest transactions with the church. You
say YOU will not settle with the unprincipled
trustecs-you would prefer settling with some Of
the backwoodsmen, whom you Could tell tuft
tale to, and wash it down with gallon OF whis-
key. Billy the trustees will neserask se'tie'
ment from you again, the law must settle It now.
Billy, your friend, the quandam, sends ms best
respects to you in cabbage leaf, to inform you
that the people who knew you where you come
from say that you were man III puphe BUSINESS
and that your habtaton was an exalted one
what the people III England calls Pasldys garrett
or the first story below the ravencnti and
that you was not inferior in your business to any
man in Dublin to give copcl polish TO a par ot
boots or shoes, and the people ,hat you are cer-
tain knew YOU when you come to this country,
and know YOU still, say when You come here you
had the respectable appearance ofa spittle-iicid
wcavcr-thlt your dutids was tackled on you
with more pins than buttons Billy, from your
respectable standing in society, We are not to
wonder at your barking like mastif dog at any
person who should attempt to bring you 10 jus
tice, but your barking is useless wo"la mo-
et e you up to proAgacy, my dear Billy, for :
bunch of matches. Your devoted friend,


] PURCELL


N. B. Patrick Higgins has document q
yours, which full proves what you are.


.

full articles.headline: FASHION.
full articles.article:
There are moments OF reflection which
press upon us in the midst of gaiety, and
they sometimes bring with them admonito-
ry lessons. We were seated in corner of
room, at the Bachelors Ball, watching
the ladies as they promenaded, and passed
a merited eulogium on the neatness OF
their dress, the propriety and modesty of
department, and their whole appearance
"They are very WELL" said friend of the
haat ron, near me, "but they are not the
I fashion of our cty--clever girls enough
4 daughters of worthy traders and industrious
mechanics; but they have not the "entree"
I into fashionable society; they are not known
4 beyond Pearl street or Chatam square.
"What constitutes fashion," "Why, wealth,
talent, certain ar---a Jeen Sais quoi" 1t
4 is wealth, there are Sin Young ladies whose
4 fathers can each draw check for 100000,
which shall be honored." MAY be So
but they wear pepper and salt CO atees with
lime on them-dine at half past one, and
Keep no carriage"


4 Thus we sum up the attributes of what is
i called fashionable life. The lady, though
y She is handsome, intelligent, rich and re-
\ spectacle, cannot be voted fashionable, un-
I I'll some priestess at the shrine, places her
q among the initiated, or some dandy declares
1 mat she will do. How absurd. In Eng
N iand, where there are hereditary claims, and
Z privileged orders, the adhesion OF the aris'
Il s.ocracs is necessary to the preservation o
4 yaeir order; but in this country, where nei
n ther fortune, birth nor talent can be entail
ea'it is ridiculous to defend such discrimin


auons The energies of clever man, arr
ssrrepressible. Half of what is called til,


.ashlon of New York-the bon ton--the We
r y y, leaders Of taste, are sprung from homes


.shors and industrious carpenters; bnt thu


ace desenerates. Fathers have raised them


sseNes by their ewn talent and enterpriz,


.10n' the bottom to the top of the ladder

full articles.headline:
TTKE WILNIINGTONIAN


AND


DELAWARE ADVERTISER.
-=----=-=t
Thursday, March 90, 1927.
full articles.article:
The President has issued his proclamation
closing the ports of the United States a
gainst all British vessels coming from any
colonial port belonging to his Britanic Ma
jesty. In allusion to the proclamation OF
the President, the Editor Of the National
Journal remarks:


"rhc law, it should seem, does not au-
thorzc the President 70 issue his Proclama
ton to take effect prospectivcly; but such
steps will of course be taken by the cxecu-
tive as candor and equity require in regard
to such vessels as are now in port, or may
arrive in the United States without having
received previous knowledge Of the presi-
dents Proclamation.


We certainly could have wished that Con
gross should have so left this matter as that
the British Government might have seen
distinctly, and in the form oflaw, the terms
on which the United States were willing TO
open the Colonial Trade TO both parties, and
full consideration Of those terms. AS Con
gress, however, saw fit to pass no new law,





carry into execution such laws as do exist,
according to its sense Of duty The contin-
gcncy provided forby existing laws has hap
pened, and Congress having risen without
altering those laws nothing has remained
to the Executive bat to give effect to those


laws, in conformity with their requirement.
.


Our advices from Portugal are favorable
to the cause and success of the friends to
the Constitution. The rebel, or royal rrces,
as they are called, have been dispersed, and
their leader, the Marquis de Chavcs, on
whom their best hopes were founded, been
put to aght-wounded and disgraced, he
has been compelled to seek an asylum in
the territory of the King Of Spain. Fer
dinand publicly disclams taking any part
in the rupture i'll Portugal, but many cir
cumstances have disclo ,cd the fact, tina,
both money and munitions of war have been
literally distributed among the disaffccted,
by his agents. We believe that tranquil,
ity will shortly be restored by the Britisi
troops; but that it will be Of long duration
is a thing quite improbable. The ambition
of the priests, who arc determined to have
their weight in the scale of all politica
measures, will keep the people continually
restless, and plot after plot will be got VI
by them, to overthrow the Constitutions
,, Government. We have no idea that an,
! plot having such an object in view, can eve
succeed. The peasantry may be reused
time after time, to take up arms and assume


the aspect of revolt, but they must as speed


lily be again put down, when the scaiiol'
l will smoke with the blood of its deiude'
t victims, and the instigators, the real wiz
workers of civil discord. will be shede
. !, from the punishment due them, by the awe
inspiring influence of the Church. The onl


safeguard to the public veal will be, wis


policy in the administration of the Govern
i ment,

All Singular Discouery.-- examined two
Ssculls last evening, and some other bones,
S$uch as rib, and one which looked like the
\ bone of chid's arm, which were taken out

Ayorkmen who were excavating the EARTH
The cistern was filled up some fifteen or
20 years ago, but the wood of which it was
&COnStI |Cl Rdi tldtl} lcinaiCd. oHS VI

Forehead, and beautifully arched eyebrows,

full articles.article: TOn SALE At THIS OFFICE

On the 18th ult the log hut Of a colored
man named Daniel Annette, was burnt, at
Ashtabula, Ohio. together with his three
children! The mans wife had left him,
and he usually locked his children in the
house during the day, which was the case
on the above fatal morning.
